title: Last of the Cybermen
author: Alan Barnes
filename: 199 - Last of the Cybermen - Alan Barnes_djvu.txt

elements.text: SCENE 1: EXT. PLANETOID [FX ONLY]
FX: LOW RUMBLES OF THUNDER. ‘LIGHTNING FLASH’ SOUND. CROSS TO:
SCENE 2: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM [CONTINUOUS]
FX: 1969 CONTROL ROOM ATMOS. THUNDER RUMBLES FROM SCANNER.
There! Did you see that, Zoe, on the scanner? — Lightning, on the horizon!
The electrical storm is getting worse.
And the thunder. Sounds like the Siege o’ Carlisle out there.
The Doctor’s been gone over an hour now. What’s keeping him?
All I know is, he told us to stay in the TARDIS, whatever happened. Sure he’1ll be done with those recambrillations of his soon enough. [SIC]
‘Recalibrations’. You didn’t really believe that, did you, Jamie?
Well, of course I — (REALISATION) What, he was lying?
There’s no sort of navigational adjustment he couldn’t make from inside the TARDIS. (SMALL LAUGH) Oh, Jamie — sometimes I think you must be one of the batch children in the artificial wood.
One o’ the [what?]
FX: ELECTRICAL FLASH FROM SCANNER.
Look!
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 3
Aye, the scanner just flared white.
Before that! I’m sure I [saw]
Och, there he is! The Doctor! Runnin’ over that ridge in the distance!
I thought so. He’s safe, thank goodness.
Safe?! — He’s not safe, Zoe!
(MILD REBUKE) Jamie. He’s five minutes away, if that.
That’s not the point. What’s he runnin’ from, eh?
Running from?
Like a fox with his brush on fire! — Which one o’ these switches opens the doors again?
Jamie, you’re not going out — (STOPS) Oh!
Hey, he’s gone again!
He was just there. There was a flash of lightning, and then — then he was gone...
You’re sayin’ he was struck by lightning?
I hope not.
That settles it. —
FX: OPERATES DOOR CONTROL. DOORS OPEN; UP STORM.
You’d best stay here, Zoe.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 4
I’1l do no such thing, Jamie McCrimmon!
Now listen here — (RECONSIDERS) Och, what’s the use?
FX: THEY RUSH OUT. DOORS CLOSE AUTOMATICALLY BEHIND.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 5
SCENE 3: EXT. PLANETOID — ROCKY RIDGE [MINUTES LATER]
FX: FADE UP. JAMIE AND ZOE CLIMBING RIDGE; SLIPPING SCREE.
THUNDER.
(HAULING HIMSELF) This rock is murder on your hands...!
(BELOW, CLIMBING) And your knees...!
Tell me about it. (LAST HAUL) Made it!
(BELOW, CLIMBING) Can you see anything?
There’s a gully just below the ridge.
Then he must have fallen in. — Help me, Jamie!
Oh, right. (HEAVING ZOE) You’re weightier than you look, for
such a wee little thing...!
(AS SHE’S PULLED) This planetoid must have a heavier-than- Earth gravity.
That'll be it. (LAST HEAVE)
(AT TOP) Thank you. (LOOKING AROUND) Well, where is he?
(OFF, IN GULLY BELOW) I don’t believe it...!
What the...?
Below us, Jamie! There!
(OFF) Zoe Heriot. Jamie McCrimmon. As I live and breathe!
Eh?! (CALLING DOWN) Who are you?
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 6
(OFF) Ah, the eternal question.
(CALLING DOWN) Are you alright?
Never mind that! —
SCENE 4: EXT. PLANETOID — IN GULLY [CONTINUOUS]
(CALLING FROM ABOVE) .. How d’you know our names?
(CALLING UP) That might be difficult to explain.
(ABOVE) Why are you lying down?
(CALLING UP) I fell. Seems to be a heavier-than-Earth gravity...
(ABOVE) We know. Have you broken anything?
That’s a thought. (AS HE CHECKS...)
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 7
SCENE 5: EXT. PLANETOID — ROCKY RIDGE [CONTINUOUS]
(OFF, IN GULLY BELOW) Just checking...!
(CALLING DOWN) Hold on, we’re coming down!
Wait a minute. Zoe, he could be anyone!
If he knows us, he’1ll know the Doctor. — Oh, come on!
CLAMBERS INTO GULLY
Zoe. Zoe! — I don’t know why I bother. (FOLLOWS)
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 8
SCENE 6: EXT. PLANETOID — IN GULLY [CONTINUOUS]
FX: AS ZOE AND JAMIE DESCEND IN BACKGROUND...
(CHECKING FEET) Tibia, fibula, talus, navicular, metatarsals, phalanges — (WINCE) Ah!
(COMING OVER) Is anything broken?
(REMEMBERING) I stubbed my toe.
Oh, is that all-?
You don’t understand. I was running. I stubbed my toe. Then, in a flash, I was here.
Yes. You fell.
No, no, the fall came after.
Are you sure you didn’t hit your head?
I was in a wood. I was running. I stubbed my toe... on a root, I remember !
(COMING OVER) Is he alright?
I think he’s had a bang on the head.
I did not bang my head! I am neither concussed, delirious, nor am I delusional!
Aye, well, seeing as you’re so alright — we’re looking for the Doctor.
The Doctor?
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 9
You know our names, you must know the Doctor.
We saw him, on the scanner. Running over yonder ridge.
(REMEMBERING) Running...
There was a flash of lightning, then he was gone. He must have fallen.
Fallen where?
(BEGINNING TO REALISE) Here. He fell here. Oh, Jamie — I think...
Yes, I appear to have swapped places with your Doctor. I was running. Your Doctor was running. There was a flash of lightning...
Then you were here.
Wherever here is.
Aye, the Doctor didn’t say.
A dwarf planet in the Kuiper belt, going by the stars.
(QUIETLY) That’s my Zoe.
‘My’ Zoe...?
Never mind where here is, where’s the Doctor?!
Wherever this man was, I expect.
It would appear that I’ve been translocated in time and space, yes.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 10
Perhaps you’1ll just switch back?
Perhaps. Or perhaps there’s a more sinister explanation. (GETTING UP) But we won’t find it at the bottom of this gully.
Wait, where d’you think you’re going?
Back to the TARDIS, of course.
TARDIS?
If I were me, and I am, I’d send myself a message via the telepathic circuits. Come on — I don’t want to keep myself waiting...
You've still not told us who you are!
Oh, Jamie. Weren’t you listening?
I was, only all the talkin’ flew right over my thick head.
I don’t know how, but this is the Doctor.
Och, don’t be ridiculous. Look at his face!
You told me he changed his face once before.
That’s only somethin’ Polly told me. Always teasin’ me, she was.
Your face changed, Jamie.
Eh?
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 11
In the Land of Fiction, remember? I had to reassemble you, from a puzzle.
Only you got the face all wrong!
To my eternal mortification. — Now please, we need to hurry.
FX: THROUGHOUT FOLLOWING SPEECH, A CYBERMAN IS CLIMBING UP
OVER THE OTHER SIDE OF THE RIDGE, UNNOTICED. SCRABBLING ON SCREE.

Why’re you in such a hurry, eh? You want to know what I think? I think, we saw the Doctor running. I think, he was running from you. I think, you’ve knocked him out and you’ve hidden him somewhere, and now you want to away and steal the TARDIS!
Old friend, I realise how all of this must sound, but [nonetheless]
(INTERRUPTING — SHE’S SEEN SOMETHING) You’re wrong, Jamie...!
Eh?
The Doctor wasn’t running from him. (ALARM) He was running from that!
(ABOVE, ON RIDGE) Stop!
A Cyberman-?!
It must have been coming up from the other side of the ridge, all the time we’ve been talking.
(TO DOCTOR) Say it, then. If you’re the Doctor, say it!
Say what-?
(ABOVE; HALTING, TIRED) Don’t run. You mustn’t run.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 12
See? He knows you.
Know him. Yes.
The other side of the gully’s too steep, we’ll never outpace ais
If that’s the case, I know just what the Doctor’d do: (FX: GRABS A ROCK FROM GROUND) “Bung a rock at it!” (EFFORT; THROWS ROCK)
FX: ROCK HITS CYBERMAN. CLANG!
Aah!
Be serious, Jamie.
(FX: GRABS ANOTHER ROCK) When I say “bung” .. bung! (EFFORT;
IT)
FX: CLANG!
Please, don’t throw rocks at me.
What did it say-?
Don’t like that, do you, you great tin horror? Well, here’s another! (EFFORT; THROWS ROCK)
Please —
FX: CLANG! CYBERMAN LOSES HIS FOOTING. SLIPPING SCREE.
It’s lost its footing!
No — (FALLS)
FX: RECEDING CLANGS AS HE FALLS OVER OTHER SIDE OF RIDGE.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 13
There. That’s how the Doctor would have dealt with it.
“Please.” It said “please”.
I noticed.
So?
Oh, Jamie. Have you ever known a Cyberman say “Please”? — Come on. (CLAMBERS UP OPPOSING RIDGE)
Och, where’s she going now?
(OFF, CLAMBERING) I want to take a look at it.
So do I. (CLIMBING AFTER ZOE) Hold on, Zoe-!
FX: FOLLOW HIM AS HE CLIMBS. CROSS TO:
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 14
SCENE 7: EXT. PLANETOID — CLIFF EDGE [CONTINUOUS]
(FROM BELOW) What’s the point? By the sounds o’ that drop, it’ll have been broken into pieces!
(CLIMBING) Oh, Jamie — where’s your curiosity?
(FROM BELOW) All I want is to find the Doctor and have us away from this wretched place!
(CLIMBING OVER TOP) Keep going, Zoe. I’m right behind you.
One last heave — (EFFORT)
BEAT AS ZOE STRAIGHTENS UP
(FROM BELOW) Well? Can you see anything?
I don’t believe it...!
(FROM BELOW) Believe what? Zoe?
You need to see! Both of you!
(LAST EFFORT; STRAIGHTENS UP) Now, what’s this something unb— [elievable] (BREAKS OFF) Gracious me.
Isn’t it amazing?
I’ve never seen anything like it.
(CLIMBING UP, BELOW) Like what?
It’s a head. A giant Cyberman head, at the top of a mountain! Why, it must be five hundred feet high!
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 15
CLIMBING OVER TOP) That’s not much of a mountain — (SEES IT
Och, you mean the head’s five hundred feet.
(SHIVER) With the lightning on it, the eyes look almost alive.
What is it, d’you suppose? A monument of some sort? Like a statue?
Cybermen don’t build monuments.
They don’t say “Please”, either. But that one did. Which reminds me... (LOOKING BELOW)
You’re not still after your metal friend?
(SCANNING) It’s a long way down. Too dark to see.
Aye, well, the Doctor’s bound to have brought his Everlasting Matches. Isn’t that right, “Doctor”?
(SEARCHING POCKETS) No... but I do have a torch.
Give it here, Doctor.
(PASSING TORCH) Careful of the edge, Zoe. It doesn’t look [stable. ]
(20 FEET BELOW) Please...
Did you hear that?
Down there, see? It’s damaged, but it’s still alive! (CALLING) Do you need help?
Help. Yes...
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 16
FX: LOUD ELECTRONIC BURBLING FILLS THE AIR. CONTINUES
THROUGHOUT.
What’s that racket it’s making?
Oh, no! — It’s a distress signal. It’s activated a distress signal.
What — more Cybermen will be coming here?
From that Cyber-citadel? Very possibly.
Citadel?!
I told you, Cybermen don’t build monuments.
Come on, let’s get out of here!
It said “Please”. It asked for our help! We can’t just leave it!

So, it said “Please”. So what? Mebbe it’s some kind of idiot Cyberman, with half of its screws loose. But if that thing’s bringing a citadel-ful of its friends down on us, we don’t want to be here — Am I right, Doctor?
He’s right, Zoe. We should get back to the TARDIS, right now!
Alright. (CALLING DOWN) I’m sorry, Mr Cyberman. We have to go n— [ooow.] (WOBBLES, BREAKS OFF AS SHE SLIPS ON SCREE)
Zoe! The edge!
Jamie, I’m falling — (CRIES OUT AS SHE...)
FX: .. TUMBLES DOWN SCREE SLOPE.
Zoe? (STEPPING FORWARD) Zoe!!!
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 17
Stay back, no sense in you both going over! — Zoe? Zoe, can you hear us?
(BELOW, GROANING) Ohhh...
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 18
SCENE 8: EXT. PLANETOID — FOOT OF CLIFF [CONTINUOUS]
FX: BURBLING CONTINUES. NEARER NOW.
(CALLING) I’m alright. It’s a scree slope, not a sheer drop.
FX: TRIES TO CLIMB BACK UP IT; SCREE SLIPPING.
Oh, but it’s like sand! There’s no climbing up it!
(ABOVE) Is there any way round the ridge?
Not that I can see. It must go on for miles!
(ABOVE) Zoe — stay there, I’m going back to the TARDIS. See if I can’t find some good strong rope...!
Please...
Well, alright...
SCENE 9: EXT. PLANETOID — CLIFF EDGE [CONTINUOUS]
FX: BURBLING CONTINUES.
(BELOW) .. just be quick about it!
Wait for me, Jamie.
You’re not coming with us.
I take it, then, that you left the TARDIS door open...?
Of course I didn’t, I.. (BREAKS OFF)
(FX: JANGLING KEY) So you’1ll be needing this.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 19
The TARDIS key!
Does that not prove anything to you?
Aye, well, you must have stolen it from the Doctor.
(BELOW) Will you two stop arguing and hurry!
(TO JAMIE) You heard the lady.
FX: THEY RUSH BACK DOWN INTO GULLY.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 20
SCENE 10: EXT. PLANETOID — FOOT OF CLIFF [CONTINUOUS]
FX: BURBLING CONTINUES. NEARER NOW.
(A FEW FEET AWAY) Please...
Why do you keep saying that?
Please. Help.
If I didn’t know better, I’d say you were in pain. — Is that it? Are you in pain?
FX: ZOE SCRAMBLES OVER TO CYBERMAN.
Oh, I see. Your leg’s trapped under a rock.
Can't... move.
(EXAMINING IT) I thought you lot were supposed to have the strength of ten men.
Please...
If I try to shift it — you won’t hurt me, will you?
No.
Do you promise?
Yes.
Cybermen don’t make promises, that’s what the Doctor would Say. (DECIDING) But I’d say you’re no ordinary Cyberman, so...
EFFORT AS SHE SHOVES ROCK
FX: ROCK MOVING.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 21
GASPS — RELIEF
Quick, I can’t hold it!
FX: LANKY SCRAMBLES OUT OF THE WAY. ZOE LETS ROCK GO. SLAM.
Better?
(GETTING UP) Much better.
It’s alright, you don’t have to get up.
(STRONG AGAIN) Much... much better!
(ALARM) Oh no...!
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 22
SCENE 11: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FX: DOORS OPEN.
In you go, then. I’m watching you, mind.
(ENTERING, FOLLOWED BY JAMIE) You know, Jamie, the humble mule is in many ways an admirable beast. But his stubbornness is
less desirable in a person.
Hey...!
Now then. Rope. Where might I find rope...?
If you were the Doctor, you’d know.
FX: CLOSES DOORS.
(SEEING CHEST ON FLOOR) My chest, I remember! (GOING TO Whatever did I do with this lovely old chest of mine?
Just get on with it, eh?
FX: DOCTOR CLICKS OPEN CHEST. CREAK AS HE RAISES LID.
That smell! All my old adventures. Jamie, I’m having a
positively Proustian remembrance.
All I’m gettin’ is mouldy socks.
CHEST)
(RUMMAGING) Fur coat. No. (FX: SHINK!) Dagger from Saladin —
was it Saladin? No. (FX: BAGPIPES HISS) Bagpipes. No...
Hey, be careful with those!
. My old ‘Paris Beau’!
That stupid hat.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 23
(PUTS ON STOVEPIPE HAT) How do I look?
No.
No. (TAKES IT OFF, RESUMES RUMMAGING) Chameleon Tours brochures. (FX: PAPER FLUMPS) No. Quark’s head. (FX: QUARK’S
CLATTERS) No. — Ah! Rope!
At last.
FX: DOCTOR PULLS ROPE, TACKLE ETC OUT OF CHEST.
Not just rope, this is mountaineering gear! — Hillary's, I recall...
FX: JAMIE TAKES ROPE.
Aye, well, you can give it back when next you see her. Right now, Zoe needs it more.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 24
SCENE 12: EXT. PLANETOID — CLIFF EDGE [MINUTES LATER]
FX: FADE UP. JAMIE AND THE DOCTOR HAUL THEMSELVES UP TO THE
RIDGE, WITH EFFORT.
Zoe, we're back! (LOOKS OVER EDGE) Zoe, where are you? — Zoe!
NO ANSWER
Well, where’s she gone?
Not just Zoe.
Hey, that Cyberman’s gone too! D’you suppose he’s taken her?
It’s an explanation.
Well, where to? — Not yon Cyber-citadel1!
We'll have to go after her. — Come on, we need to belay this rope.
(UNCOILING ROPE) This is all your fault. If you hadn’t insisted on going off out of the TARDIS alone —
Then you do accept I’m the Doctor?
(NON-COMMITALLY) Mebbe.
Well, I can hardly be held responsible for the manifold idiocies of my former incarnations.
Hey, are you calling my Doctor an idiot?
Heading off to explore a Cybermen citadel alone? I’d call that pretty idiotic.
Aye, well, he must have had a reason.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 25
Yes. — Yes, I suppose I must...
Och, you can’t remember, I suppose.
No, I can’t. Which is something of a worry.
Old age, aye.
No! — I mean, I can believe that I went out to have a look around, then got chased back to the TARDIS by a Cyberman...
Happens all the time.
Precisely. But if Zoe had got herself kidnapped by a Cyberman, and taken to a giant Cyber-citadel.. well, I’m sure I’d have remembered that.
FX: UNDER THE FOLLOWING, WE HEAR A ‘SPACE HELICOPTER’
FAST, FROM THE DIRECTION OF THE CITADEL.
So?
So.. what if none of this would have happened, if your Doctor hadn’t been translocated?
So you’re sayin’ it is all your fault n—[ow?] (BREAKS OFF,
HELICOPTER-LIKE FLYER; ROTORS) Hey, do you hear that?
Jamie, behind you!
Whuh-? (SEES FLYER) Oh, aye — it’s a helicopter!
Rotors on the bottom, it’s an anti-gravity flyer.
Alright, then, a space helicopter. (CALLING, WAVING HANDS) Over here!!!
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 26
What do you think you’re doing?
Calling them over. We’ll have no trouble finding Zoe ina helicopter.
Anti-gravity flyer. Jamie, there could be anyone in there!
Won’t be Cybermen, though. You ever seen a Cyberman in a hel— (CORRECTS SELF) — anti-gravity flyer?
Well, no, admittedly —
Cybermen have flyin’ saucers for that. — There, look, he’s
seen us.
All the same, I don’t think it’s wise, calling them over.
Aye, well, it’s what I’m doing.
(SIGHS) Stubborn like the proverbial mule.
Hey, now — that’s the second time you’ve called me that!
FX: FLYER HOVERING CLOSE BY NOW.
(GRABBING JAMIE) Come on, back into the gully.
Get your hands off me!
We don’t know who’s in that thing. We need to get under cover.
(SHOVE) Don’t you tell me what to do!
(SHOVE) Or what?
(SHOVE) Or... or I’1l punch you on the nose!
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 27
(SHOVE) Well, maybe I’11 punch you right back!
Let’s see now, shall w—
FX: SUDDENLY, JAMIE IS BLASTED DOWN BY AN ENERGY WEAPON FROM
THE FLYER.
CRIES OUT, COLLAPSES
Jamie! — Jamie! (TO FLYER) Well, what did you do that for? Blasting him down for no reas-[on]
FX: ANOTHER ENERGY BLAST. DOCTOR FLUMPS TO GROUND. FADE OUT ON
ROTORS.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 28
SCENE 13: INT. STOREROOM
FX: REVERSE ECHO INTO:
Doctor. Wake up. Doctor! — Och, snap out of it, you great clown!
(SUDDENLY AWAKE) Jamie! Where the devil — (REALISATION) My
hands are tied!
Aye, behind your back. Mine too. Some sort of plastic cuff. That’s why I woke you up.
(STRUGGLING) Plastic’s the worst. — And before you ask, no; even if I could reach my pockets, I’ve not got my sonic screwdriver.
Thought that’d be too much to expect. But that’s not why I woke you up.
It isn’t?
Shimmy along on your backside, see if you can’t reach my dirk.
I beg your pardon-?
My dagger. In my sock-?
Of course. One moment — (EFFORT; SHIMMIES AROUND) Have you been awake long? That stun beam could have felled an elephant.
But not a stubborn Scottish mule — is that what you’re sayin’?
(FEELING JAMIE’S ANKLE) Funny, I can’t feel it.
Other leg.
Sorry. (MORE SHIMMYING) Where are we, anyway?
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 29
Don’t know. Storeroom, I suppose.
If this is a cupboard, it’s distinctly bare.
Aye, just a few wee metal boxes on the floor.
Oh, yes. (FINDS DAGGER) There, got it! Turn around with your back to me.
Can’t you cut your own first?
I can try.
Good, ‘cause I’d rather you slashed your wrists than mine.
Charming. (FX: BEGINS SAWING AWAY AT PLASTIC TIE)
And don’t take your time about it. We need to cut along and find out what’s happened to Zoe...
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 30
SCENE 14: INT. CITADEL CONTROL ROOM
What were you doing out there on the surface? — Talk!
I’m not saying a single word. Not until you bring me Jamie and the Doctor.
Please. It’d be better if you talked.
I rescued you. I helped you out when you were trapped, and what thanks do I get? I get seized — rather roughly seized, I might add —
Sorry. I don’t know me own strength sometimes.
. seized, and dragged off to this citadel to be interrogated by — (BREAKS OFF) Did you just say “sorry”?
Please, Ms Zennox. This girl Zoe has shown us only kindness. Let’s give her the benefit.
She tried to repair what she thought was a Cyberman, we’re right to be suspicious.
I made him better because he said “please”. What kind of Cyberman says “please”, and “sorry”, and talks about kindness?
FX: DOOR SLIDES OPEN, OFF.
You’re right... Zoe. I’m not a Cyberman.
(WALKING IN THROUGH DOOR) Not where it matters, at least.
Captain Frank! Did you recover the girl’s associates?
Of course.
The Doctor and Jamie! Where are they?
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 31
Had to give them a blast of Hermione’s knockout ray. Shut ‘em up in a storeroom so they could sleep it off.
Why? Did they try to attack you?
Great Jupiter, no. I was trying to stop them killing each other, in fact.
Don’t tell me they were fighting!
Slugging it out like a pair of burned-out mek-boxers, right on the edge of a rock face. Don’t worry — I’ve put ‘em in plasti- cuffs. For their own safety, of course.
Oh no. — They’re friends, really they are.
“Priends”?
It’s hard to explain.
I told you, I’m not a Cyberman... lass.
Lanky here knows all about friends. We’re best chums, him and I — isn’t that right, Lanky?
The Captain and me, we were comrades-in-arms. Fighter pilots, in the Great Cyber-War. I were shot down in the skies above Telos, and taken for Cyber-conversion. The Captain went back for me, though.
Pulled him out of the machinery — er, just before those monsters converted his brain.
(JUTTING IN) Too late to save the rest of me, mind.
But still, he went back for you.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 32
Sticking by your mates through thick and thin, that’s friendship.
Now, now, old chap. Let’s not get sentimental.
Yes, we wouldn’t want him leaking oil.
So there are no real Cybermen here? Bad Cybermen. Oh, you know what I mean.
Where’ve you been, lass?
The Cybermen were utterly defeated, ten Earth years ago.
Those tin terrors never stood a chance, not once the Johnnies in Space Ordnance had come up with the Glittergun.
Glittergun?
It turned out that a design flaw in the Cybermen’s respiratory apparatus made them vulnerable to gold dust.
Really?
So if you’re wearing any jewellery, you stay away from me!
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 33
SCENE 15: INT. STOREROOM
FX: DOCTOR CUTTING THROUGH JAMIE’S BONDS.
Careful, eh?
I can be trusted with the simplest task, you know. —
FX: PINK! AS JAMIE’S TIE IS CUT THROUGH.
Ah, that’s better. — I’1l have my dirk back now, if you don’t mind.
With pleasure. (HANDS IT OVER)
(TAKING DIRK BACK) Good. (FX: AS DOCTOR CROSSES TO DOOR:) You surely don’t think that door’1ll just open?
(FX: LIFTING METAL FLAP) Looks like the mechanism is triggered by a small electrical charge...
What, an electric key?
Like the low charge that Cybermen generate.
We’re in that Cyber-citadel, then?
I'd have thought so, wouldn’t you?
Bet you’re wishing you had your sonic screwdriver now.
All I need’s a few amps to trip it. The battery from my torch would have done it.
Aye, but you don’t have that, either.
FX: DOCTOR CROSSES FLOOR.
LAST OF THE CYBERMEN by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 34
These “wee metal boxes...”
FX: PICKS UP ONE OF THE METAL BOXES.
Hey, is there something inside there?
I don’t know.
Give it a shake, then.
